list_definition.definition: in music, a sign eg or on the stave fixing the pitch of the notes

list_ex_of_english: Clef usage and the range of the individual parts offer some help where instrumental designations are lacking.
I have become fascinated with romans a clef, a very popular genre in the eighteenth century.
This is made possible by writing the music without clefs or key signatures, allowing the singers to assume those suited to the chosen mode.
Some elements of the roman a clef can be found throughout the text.
Another peculiar aspect of the notation of partimento fugues resides in the numerous clef changes, which can even be found after the exposition.
It must be said, however, that the absence of clefs in the fragment makes it impossible to be quite certain about the pitch levels intended.
Is it at all possible to find a few books that are all in the same mode and the same clef?
The first is an incorrect clef.
